goal: Investigating the reporting and composition of the Shenbao (1872-1891) to understand how news defined individuals' notability in late imperial China through digital methodologies.
methods: Employing natural language processing (NLP), named entity recognition (NER), network analysis, and topic modeling to process articles and analyze individuals and organizations mentioned in the Shenbao.
process: Building a dataset of 130,485 unique articles filtered for quality, applying NER to identify entities like persons and institutions, cleaning data for standardization, and visualizing patterns through network and topic modeling.
results: Identified dominance of public officials and institutions in the Shenbao's content, revealing the newspaper's reliance on official sources and highlighting disparities in mentions, with only 3.1% of names appearing more than five times.
